data.title: Polished the Dune 2000 shellmap harvester delivery
data.body: as suggested in https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/7273#issuecomment-68924296.

data.title: Moved connection UI to OpenRA.Mods.Common
data.body: This is required for https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/4496.

data.title: Removed glitchy decorations from DESERT tileset
data.body: A followup of https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/5372. Split from https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/pull/4496.

data.title: Vastly improve shroud rendering performance.
data.body:
Changes in the shroud are now tracked. If a cell changes it will mark itself and its neighbours as dirty. During the render phase all dirty cells will have their vertices calculated and cached. If a cell is not dirty, the pre-calculated vertices are retrieved from cache. Then the sprite renderer is provided the sprite and the pre-calculated vertices to draw.

This prevents constant recalculation of vertices for the shroud in the render phase, requiring instead only dirty cells in the visible area. The update phase is reduced to a practical noop, instead incurring the cost only of changed cells each frame, rather than checking the visible area.

---

This is a revival of #7095 with some updates. I initially thought @pchote's proof on concept would be the same for performance, and it was far less code so I thought it'd be a better choice.

Sadly it's not. You need to update the cell and its 8 neighbours. If you generate vertices right away you end up doing a substantial amount of work that can easily be avoided by delaying the work until you actually need to render the vertices.

I tested this version, and saw total CPU time for rendering the shroud drop from 28% (told you it was expensive!) to 9% of all CPU time spent.

In theory, this means if you get a solid 50 fps, you could now be getting 60 fps instead!

data.title: Make global chat the default mode in the ingame chat widget
data.body: Currently, the in-game chat widget starts off in team chat mode. This changes it so that global chat is selected and alt-tab has to be used to switch to team chat.

data.title: Lobby admin tooltip shows the local (player) client instead of "local host" on OS X
data.body:
![screen shot 2015-01-10 at 10 36 46](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/167819/5688238/98b0bc6c-98b9-11e4-9bd3-72a6ecf164de.png)

This was apparently not reproduced by the windows-using players in the server.

data.title: Move the mod dependencies to the test/check rules.
data.body: This moves the mod dll dependencies on to the test and check rules, which are the things that actually depend on them.  The utility doesn't need the mod dlls at compile time, but they are needed by anything that runs the utility (because the mod dlls contain the utility commands).

data.title: Updated year numbers in all files
data.body:
Hope, I didn't miss something.

Should I squash the commits?

data.title: Carryall edge spawn & Harvester delivery
data.body:
This spawns the Carryall under either fog, shroud or -when that's not available- at the map edge.

It has already been debated whether that's the way to go, but looking at original d2k I really believe this is the best way. 

Next PR would be harvester insurance (in case of worm frenzy)

data.title: Reorder Travis build command orders
data.body: Two more tweaks in the spirit of #7294.

data.title: Add repairing and unit repaired sounds to ra service depo
data.body:
In TD and D2K it currently only plays the "repairing" sound when entering a service depo
(because they don't have "unit repaired" notifications).
Should that stay that way, or should I use `StartRepairingNotification = null;` as default?

Moves the following to Common:

data.title: Reorder the Makefile
data.body:
Reorder the "test" and "check" sections of the Makefile in order to run the faster/more likely-to-blow-up things first.
See #7279 for reference.

data.title: Remove husks prematurely if they are blocking a production building's exit
data.body:
A husk standing in front of your tank factory can be really annoying. It could also hurt you if you are in a hurry to get more vehicles out on the field.

Here you see a destroyed Devastator's husk blocking the Heavy Factory's exit, and the MCV, which is ready, is just waiting inside, blocking the production of any other units as well:
![](http://i.imgur.com/jBaXNwO.png)

data.title: Adjust UpgradeOverlay.ModifyRender to be more efficient.
data.body: When IsTraitDisabled is set, ModifyRender doesn't actually alter the sequence, so we can just return it directly and avoid adding another layer of enumerable. If it is unset, then the modifying enumerable has one less condition to check inside the loop.

data.title: Implement dynamic hardware palette sizing.
data.body:
The HardwarePalette will now grow its palette buffer and texture in power-of-2 increments. This avoids it having to allocate memory for a full 256x256 texture up front. In practice the default mods use 22 or 23 palettes so a 32x256 texture is used. This means both the buffer and texture save neatly on memory. Additionally, HardwarePalette.ApplyModifiers sees a nice speedup as it has to transfer a much smaller amount of memory from the buffer to the texture.

To facilitate this change, the MaxPalettes constant is no longer publicly exposed. Instead the PaletteReference deals with the calculation of the index and this is passed into the appropriate methods.

data.title: Create Sandworm art
data.body:
The sandworm's behavior is being done and redone, but because the original sandworm was drawn by the engine, there is no animation we can use.

> [23:30] penev__> aaaaand we still don't have proper artwork for them, too
> [23:34] MicroBit> penev__ : as far as i heard ... its code related ... the "art" for the worm
> [23:35] +pchote> in the original game, yeah
> [23:35] +pchote> somebody will need to make some sprites for us
> [23:35] MicroBit> why is nobody doing it via "code" ?
> [23:35] +pchote> because it is a real PITA to do it in code on our engine
> [23:35] +pchote> which works completely different graphics-wise to the original games
> [23:37] MicroBit> tbh. i have no idea how to do the art to make it look like the original
> [23:39] +pchote> that animation you did ages ago looked like it would have worked
> [23:39] +pchote> with the spray paint mspaint tool, or whatever you used
> [23:40] MicroBit> yeah ... but that is just 1 cell ...
> [23:40] +pchote> the code would then need to overlap it a bunch of times
> [23:40] +pchote> which is what the original games did
> [23:40] MicroBit> i dont think so
> [23:40] +pchote> they were drawn with pixel positioning instead of cell positioning
> [23:41] MicroBit> looks damn fluid
> [23:44] MicroBit> penev__ : why not asking for help in the modding section of "sleipnir stuff" ?
> [23:46] MicroBit> pchote : i bet worm-sprites will cause some uglyness when they overlap or cut "rock" tiles
> [23:47] +pchote> I bet they do in the original game, too
> [23:47] MicroBit> the do indeed
> [23:47] MicroBit> but guess what
> [23:47] MicroBit> the color even changes
> [23:48] MicroBit> like ... it gets more redish ... or darker
> [23:48] MicroBit> depends on what tiles the worm is diving under
> [23:50] +pchote> that's because of the blending mode they use

Not to mention that lightnings around the worm should be only at random times (that could easily be achieved in the `Sandworm` trait once the current constant lightning animation is replaced with something else).

So someone will have to step up and make ... something. Please!

data.title: Speed up depth sorting of renderables.
data.body:
By inlining the calls to ScreenZPosition in the compare method, we can cancel some terms around the comparison and improve performance. The comparer has been moved and renamed in order to make its function more obvious, and to help ensure the comparison stays in sync with the ScreenZPosition function.

This reduces time spent doing compares from 5.0% to 3.0%.

data.title: Added all ra notifications to notifications.yaml
data.body:
I renamed "Win" to "MissionAccomplished" and "Lose" to "MissionFailied", because IMHO it sounds more reasonable and added "Repairing" and "Unit repaired" notifications to the service depo, as well.

Updated some year numbers and fixed a stupid mistake in utility.cmd (td vs cnc).

The notifications can be tested with [this lua code](https://gist.github.com/abcdefg30/651546fd409e01f401a0).

data.title: Atreides can build Corrino structures.
data.body: Regression from #7147.  The Corrino starport also has the build icon of a combat tank.

data.title: Improve the fire animation position on D2K husks.
Sardaukar infantry shoot at flying carryalls
Move more traits to Mods.Common
data.body:
After @reaperrr's big effort with the buildings, some things got a lot easier to move.
The PR is divided into 4 self-contained commits for those who find it easier to review commit-by-commit ;)

Also something I just thought - perhaps we should make all `Traits`, `Orders`, `Activities`, `Effects`, etc. in `Mods.Common` `public`? After all, the idea (one of them) is to provide people with an engine they can mod/use/build upon, right?
While traits can be used in YAMLs without being public (right?), they can't be used in third-party DLLs. Same for `Orders`, `Activities`, etc.

data.title: Cache render related TraitsImplementing calls in Actor.
data.body:
The TraitsImplementing<T> performs a dictionary lookup to match up its generic type parameter with the right trait collection. Since actors are rendered so much, it is useful to cache this result to avoid looking it up repeatedly.

This saves 1.4% in CPU time that was being spent calling these methods in the RA shellmap.

data.title: Require an actor with an active ProvidesRadar trait to be notified of a NukePower launch.
data.body:
I initially attempted to do this through Upgrades on the PlayerActor but we don't have a method to test whether or not an actor has a particular upgrade and I could not write a working one.

This is the example from #7218.

data.title: Change the order in which Makefile commands are executed?
data.body:
With all the recent additions for CI and style enforcing, the automated builds have become annoyingly slow. The "make test" section is taking Travis a long time (mainly due to the amount of maps for RA).
This could be very annoying for new people (or ones who forget, like me) to wait for it to finish only to break on "make check", because you forgot to run the check locally (I only do when I get reminded of it).
I don't think it would be unreasonable to move "make check" before "make test". Anyone else?

Also "make test" runs in the following order:  RA (63 maps), TD (32 maps), D2k (12 maps), TS (2 maps). This can be really annoying if you want to check D2k or TS, which only take a few seconds, unlike the previous.

I think when dealing with potential "crashes" that might make you start over it is best to move the faster checks before the slower ones.
I'm opening an issue instead of a PR because I want to hear some feedback first.
